report_title: Magazine & Periodical Publishing in the US
executive_summary: Magazine and periodical publishers sell print and digitized versions, but plummeting print advertising and low product popularity have led to a steady drop in revenue. Advertisers and consumers have devoted more time, energy and dollars to online publications and digital channels, forcing companies to bolster their online presence and shrink their print business. Revenue is estimated to fall an annualized 1.5% to $40.1 billion in 2024, including a 4.3% dip in 2024 alone as profit slides to 7.3%.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Print's Hold on the Magazine and Periodical Business Has Given Way to Other Media Types
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Print magazine and periodical subscriptions and sales have fallen behind digital media platforms. Magazines still sell in grocery stores and pharmacies, but online sales now account for almost half of publishing revenue. Social media, blogs, television and streamed video content have battled with magazines and periodicals for audiences. Entertainment magazines have struggled to compete with celebrity-focused social media and television programs like TMZ and E!. The transition from a print-dominated industry to a digital one has been far from smooth.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Digital Will Surpass Print's Share of the Total Magazine and Periodical Publishing Revenue
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Digital magazine and periodical publishing's share of total revenue will likely surpass its print counterpart, possibly by a wide margin. The whole economy has shifted online, forcing print to follow in the footsteps of news media and record companies.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Consolidation Will Continue to Diversify Media Companies' Product Suites
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Companies will consolidate to form multimedia conglomerates, leaving less room for new publishers to enter the market. Articles, videos, podcasts, and social media posts will become part of larger companies' product suites.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Trade and Academic Journals Will Remain Relatively Fractured
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Trade and academic journals will remain relatively fractured because of the niche focuses customers need. Some journals may benefit from mergers that offer multiple titles, each covering a specific topic within a broader category.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Print Publishers Consider Going Niche and Premium or Broad and Aggregated
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Magazines and periodicals may focus on niche, premium product offerings to continue creating print content. Some publishers have aggregated titles instead of focusing on premium niche content.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Shifting Economic Conditions Come as a Relief to Publishers
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Improving consumer sentiments and per capita disposable income will enable magazine and periodicals publishers to stay afloat, as buyers become more encouraged to make discretionary purchases.

industry_definition: This industry produces and distributes magazines and periodicals in print and online. However, publishers that exclusively sell online magazines or periodicals are excluded from this industry.

negative_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: low - steady

key_trends: Profit has held steady thanks to staff layoffs and cutbacks on printing and ink. Digital companies still contend with the costs of managing websites and earn less advertising and subscriber revenue per reader than print-focused publishers.
Some companies will focus on highly niche premium content to stay relevant in print. Others will aggregate titles to cover a broad range.

market_segmentation.segment: Print Magazines' Place at the Top of the Industry is Being Threatened
market_segmentation.segment_description: Entertainment and home living magazines rely heavily on the print market. Many companies place physical copies of magazines in checkout lines or offices to entice customers. Waiting areas do not feel the pressure to restock with new magazines in the age of smartphones.

market_segmentation.segment: Digital Magazine Advertisements and Subscriptions Have Climbed
market_segmentation.segment_description: Scientific and business journals have successfully transitioned to the digital market. Professionals rely heavily on fact-checked information from published journals. Academics and corporations subscribe in bulk to these journals, ensuring consistent revenue.

market_segmentation.segment: Magazine and Periodical Publishers Help Produce and Distribute Other Magazines' Content
market_segmentation.segment_description: Companies provide external publishing services to independent authors to promote, edit or distribute content. Publishers have increasingly attempted to diversify their offerings in order to shield against the erosion of demand for print publishing.

products_and_services.product_description: Entertainment magazines include arts, culture, fashion, and leisure titles.
Academic and professional titles reach niche audiences with complex and hard-to-find content.
Home and living magazines remain popular among homeowners, flipping through magazines to find anything from recipes to patio layouts.
Political magazines and periodicals reach a wider audience, not just those working in politics.
Some magazines earn revenue from hosting events like conferences, debates, or product viewings. Advertisers leverage a magazine brand to attract customers to sponsored events.

tier_2_suppliers: Coated & Laminated Paper Manufacturing in the US
Internet Service Providers in the US
tier_1_buyers: Media Buying Agencies in the US
Book, Magazine & Newspaper Wholesaling in the US
tier_2_buyers: Professional, Scientific and Technical Services in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Entertainment Tabloids Form the Backbone of Magazine Publishing but Struggle to Compete with Television and Social Media
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Entertainment magazines include arts, culture, fashion, and leisure titles. Entertainment titles tend to be balanced in advertising and subscription revenue and have historically benefited from broad retail distribution and placement near points of sale, encouraging impulse purchases and providing advertisers with a wide reach.

Home and living magazines remain popular among homeowners, flipping through magazines to find anything from recipes to patio layouts. Home and garden television programs compete with these magazines but tend to target a younger market.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: NICHE TOPICS COVERED IN JOURNALS AND PROFESSIONAL MAGAZINES HAVE SUCCESSFULLY TRANSITIONED TO ONLINE MEDIA
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Academic and professional titles reach niche audiences with complex and hard-to-find content. These titles generate the most revenue from subscriptions and have been less affected by declining ad sales. Sales remain consistent thanks to subscriptions from the business community and universities.

business_locations.location_description: The Great Lakes region has experienced an upswing in business activity, attracting publishers to the area. The area acts as a manufacturing hub for much of the nation, making it an attractive home for businesses. The Great Lakes region is also home to several colleges and universities, giving publishers who locate in the region access to potential talent.

The Mid-Atlantic has a large consumer and business market. Corporate and university periodical subscriptions drive sales and consumers shopping at grocery stores. Many of the nation's top newspapers and magazines come from this region.

The Southeast region has a large and diverse market that drives magazine sales. The region has a diverse population from around the world and the United States, prompting advertisers to engage with the Southeast. A significant elderly population may drive print magazine sales in the Southeast. Many retirees shop at grocery stores and enjoy purchasing entertainment, home-living magazines, and physical copies of journals.

regulations_points.regulation_description: To qualify for periodical status with the US Post Office, magazines and journals must regularly issue at a stated frequency, have multiple consecutive issues, issue at least four times a year, have a set list of subscribers and earn less than 75.0% of mailed content revenue from advertising.
Copyright Act of 1976 restricts the reproduction of copyrighted work according to the owner's discretion. The Copyright Act introduced the concept of fair use into copyright law.

According to the US State Department, libel and defamation law varies depending on the subject's status as a private or public figure. The landmark 1964 Supreme Court case New York Times Co. v. Sullivan set national standards for libel regarding public figures.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Magazine publishers must hire photographers, salespeople, and writers, including freelance photographers and writers, to reduce costs.

barriers_points.barrier_title: Staff needed for digital and print content
barriers_points.barrier_description: Digital and print-focused magazines and journals use staff to moderate and edit content.

basis_points.basis_title: Magazine and periodical publishers have merged with software and multimedia companies
basis_points.basis_description: Large magazine and journal companies now include television and educational software in their product suites.

basis_points.basis_title: Trade and academic journals remain competitive
basis_points.basis_description: Trade and academic journals have successfully shifted to digital publications and remain competitive. Customers looking for niche topics subscribe to specific journals, keeping this market fractured.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Internal and External Consolidation Helps Publishers Compete
concentration_points.concentration_description: Magazine companies have combined internal titles to reach more customers and reduce costs. Segmented publications that are related but fall under the same umbrella can be combined into one title to save on costs. A similar trend has occurred in health magazines combined with fitness titles.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Publishers Have Transitioned to Multimedia and Software Companies
concentration_points.concentration_description: Large magazine and periodical publishers have acquired smaller publishers to gain readers and find cost synergies. Magazines and periodicals have struggled to generate organic growth within their target markets. Fewer magazines and journals focus on each topic, leading to market concentration.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Magazine and periodical publishers rely on skilled writers and photographers to produce engaging content for readers. Companies have cut wages amid falling subscriber numbers and advertiser revenue. Publishers can cut costs by reducing staff and using freelance writers and photographers.

Paper, ink, and other raw material purchases enable print-focused publishers to produce magazines and periodicals. Postage also represents a high cost for companies to deliver magazines to their customers. These expenses have given way to digital-related costs like running websites and investing in IT infrastructure. Magazine and periodical publishers purchase content from freelance writers, photo services, and other creative content.
High rates of mergers and acquisitions have kept legal fees elevated, while inventory costs have fallen with the transition to digital content.
Magazine and periodical publishers attend and host promotional events to market their content and brand. Companies can reach target markets by placing their content alongside related products.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Magazine publishers must hire photographers, salespeople, and writers, including freelance photographers and writers, to reduce costs.
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Digital and print-focused magazines and journals use staff to moderate and edit content.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Low levels of innovation limit the threat to incumbent operators from new technologies disrupting their operations.
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: However, a low rate of growth in technology can also create exposure for incumbents as the trajectory of innovation in other markets could lead to unforeseen competitive disadvantages.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: The major markets for this industry are highly concentrated, which implies that the market has a focus on key customer segments.
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: This presents an opportunity for strategic entrance into lower-end markets or unserved markets for innovations to take on a disruptive trajectory.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Revenue has continued to decrease amid the rise of digital content, which has increased competition for the industry. The emergence of the digital medium has coincided with a dearth of print advertising expenditure.
Advertising revenue account for a large portion of industry revenue, therefore, fluctuations in advertising markets affect industry revenue. Advertising spending is sensitive to economic conditions.
Magazine and periodical publishing revenue correlate with advertising expenditures and corporate profit. Both plummeted in 2020 as companies resisted reinvesting in advertising, especially print.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Digital readers, on average, generate less revenue than print subscribers because of lower advertising fees and subscription fees relative to print.
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Most of a magazine's costs stem from producing creative content, not creating the print itself.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Entertainment Tabloids Form the Backbone of Magazine Publishing but Struggle to Compete with Television and Social Media
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Social media has led to the constant creation of free celebrity-driven content. Celebrity-focused networks like TMZ and E! also compete with entertainment magazine publishers.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Niche Topics Covered in Journals and Professional Magazines Have Successfully Transitioned to Online Media
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Academic and professional titles reach niche audiences with complex and hard-to-find content. These titles generate the most revenue from subscriptions and have been less affected by declining ad sales.

FAQs.question: How have changes in individual consumer electronic use changed your operations?
FAQs.answer: The rise of smart devices has increased consumption of electronic media, hurting print publications. Digital advertising revenue is lower than print advertising revenue, and the move to digital has made industry publications more accessible without the need of taking out a subscription or buying a copy in print.

FAQs.question: How reliant is your company on advertising revenue?
FAQs.answer: Although magazines have focused on building subscription revenue, advertising continues to account for a majority of magazine publishing revenue. For some operators, this is slowly shifting as consumers take out digital subscriptions in higher volumes and advertisers cut back on print advertising, which generates more revenue than digital advertising.

FAQs.question: Is your company strategically located in a region that acts to your benefit?
FAQs.answer: Locating in a major media market can give magazine publishers easier access to talented writers, editors and other creative professionals. However, the industry as a whole remains highly disbursed due to the variety of local publications that exist throughout the country.

FAQs.question: Are you paying wages above or below what your competitors pay?
FAQs.answer: Magazines have pursued a variety of strategies to reduce labor costs, including reliance on freelance workers. However, retaining top talent at the largest magazines still requires operators to pay a substantial portion of their revenue in wages.

FAQs.question: Has your company been able to keep current with changing digital interfaces?
FAQs.answer: As magazines increasingly move online, they must adopt the latest tools available for providing digital content. Digital tools introduced amid the coronavirus pandemic by some operators, including dashboards that track the spread of the novel coronavirus, have <UNKNOWN>. Some new software has become available to automate certain content creation, particularly in video and data-heavy reporting topics. Advances in software have also improved the user interfaces of operators' online magazine editions.

FAQs.question: Which niches, if any, do you cater to? How can you diversify your product mix?
FAQs.answer: The ability to identify and service niche markets is important. This may entail online offerings for some periodicals, while others rely on readers to provide content.

FAQs.question: How do you attract and retain qualified staff? What qualifications must your staff have?
FAQs.answer: Access to high-quality staff is important. Good staff can promote and support customer service, the reputation of existing publications, the production of new publications and the timely delivery of products.

FAQs.question: Do you manufacture any branded products? How do you promote your products and services?
FAQs.answer: Brand names are important in this industry because they can influence buyers' perceptions and help drive sales. Operators therefore invest heavily in marketing their magazines to consumers, even as they themselves rely on downstream advertising expenditures by clients.

FAQs.question: What percentage of your revenue is generated from print advertising? Are there other revenue streams on which you can focus?
FAQs.answer: Print advertising expenditure closely follows corporate profit and overall economic conditions, but is undercut by new opportunities in internet-based advertising. As the industry wide shift away from print advertising and toward digitization continues, the industry will have to adapt.

FAQs.question: What are your main sources of competition? Have you expanded your publication with a complementary website?
FAQs.answer: The most direct competition comes from internet-only periodicals (which have lower production and distribution costs), blogs and other websites. In recent years, social media and other online entertainment and streaming sites have also posed a threat to industry operators. As a result, operators have increased their social media presence and their presence on sites such as YouTube.

FAQs.question: Do you track changes in disposable income? How does affect your subscription rates?
FAQs.answer: A dip in disposable income limits the purchasing power of consumers, resulting in decreased circulation of magazines and lower industry revenue.
